text: this for me this is kind of
quintessential
dandyism in as much as you have a figure
here who's all masculine but also very
feminine whom is deliberately blurring
some ideas about masculinity and it's
performing an idea of what it can be to
look black and male really you know men
spend a lot of time making it up as they
go along making up the idea of what it
means to be a man making up male
identity when did being black and
fashionable become if you like a
statement not not just something that
you did because you want to feel good
but it was a statement I think being
black and stylish and fashionable these
things have always gone together they've
gone together historically actually for
hundreds of years specifically when it
comes really to the position that the
black men hold in in Western society
very often black men are marginalized
are stereotyped and defined in kind of
objective and often quite offensive
terms is kind of brute and ultra
masculine and hyper sexualized and some
and so there becomes a politics around
dressing dressing stylishly
and the clothes I'm wearing aren't just
a sort of superficial thing they're
actually a statement of how I want to
comport myself how I want to conduct
myself how I want to hold myself in the
street how I want to be visible on my
terms
